review_title: Can't figure how to enter any museum...
one_reviews_text: The controls are stupid with Oculus Touch. Can't figure out how to actually enter any of the museum, still stuck in the lobby.... This is really poor UX.
Great Art, and the worst gamedesign in the human history
I've just spent some minutes trying to figure out how to enter a museum. Finally givng up and uninstalling.

Like everyone else said, the controls are horrid, BUT the actual exhibits and VO are very high quality once you get into them. If the controls worked like every other VR experience, this would be a five-star exhibit.

Just get close to the panel on the wall that you want to visit until it flattens out. Then, slowly turn right until the "Start" button on the wall highlights in green, then press the A button.

Pros : Thankfully it isn't 360 degree video.
         It's free.

Con : Ultimately let down by the janky control and UI system. Most applications have a default movement system, which hopefully most are used to now, this throws that all out the window and turns it on its head. I gave up after 10 minutes.

There are better museum experiences in Sansar.
Something is really wrong with this update.

review_title: More intuitive UI will make it better.
one_reviews_text: Inspite of the on-screen guide, it was not so intuitive or easy to adapt me to the UI. Quite frequently I had to struggle to figure out why my touch controller did not select the menu items. Resultantly I could not enjoy the exhibition at all. More intuitive and responsive UI could provide far better VR museum experience.
What you get when you let a five year old design the user interface. Don't waste your time. I'd give it a zero if I could .

review_title: Wow, best VR museum app by miles
one_reviews_text:
Entering the museum issues aside (I had no problems) this is clearly miles ahead of other apps of this type. I've recently studied a bucketload of these app types for a paper, and this is hands-down the best I tried. Firstly, the exhibitions in here are interesting, high profile examples you may know from real life. Unlike other Museum apps, this is converting real exhibitions into VR form. The galleries are even authentic in appearance. 
Not only are the exhibits the highest resolution I've seen and stand up to closest scrutiny (especially the paintings, which really helps evoke a good sense of presence), the multiple VO choices are all excellent, informative and interesting, and every one of the 6 galleries has cool secrets to unearth. Go inside a Manet painting, visit the NY workspace where the art was created, retheme the gallery space, etc. Full of meaningful little touches. Head and shoulders above most of the other apps I've seen. If you're interested at all in this, I highly recommend it.

Apps like Boulevard were the reason I bought an Oculus. But it is perfectly unusuable. It locks you into an information screen that you can't exit, and while that screen is displayed, you cannot move around and enter anything.

review_title: Never got out of the lobby
one_reviews_text: Tried for 10 minutes to enter one of the exhibitions, but its just not possible in any logical way.  If a developer cares so little about user experience, its best to stay away.

Instruction how to enter a Museum
----------------------------------------------------------------

when entering the lobby, select "tutorial"  "No" on the tablet and confirm with the right "A" button.  Now move forward with the left thumbstick. When in hight of the first banner turn right with the right thumbstick. Again approach the banner with the left stick. Point with your right arm and stretched index finger to the  @ENTER symbol until it turns green. Now press the "A" botton again to enter that museum.

This is a very high grade museum application (especially entring the first banner, leading to the British Museum). 

However it is a shame to design the lobby mechanics so purely, that 90% of the users do not find the entry.  This leaded to a completetly unnecessary 2 star rating where five stars would be more appropriate.

Regards, Thomas.

review_title: I wanted this to work but it doesn't
one_reviews_text: The idea is great.  The paintings have a quality look to them, and I could see how this could be a real boon to imobilized people.  The ability to move through and choose what you have an interest in while getting quality narration about the work should be fantastic.  Sadly an alien designed the control functions.  I am not sure what sort of appendages would be required to have these controls make sense, but there would have to be very odd to us.  When you guys get a "human 1.0" update let us know.  I will update my ranking.

If you want to be in the body of a woman with loud shoes, who can't walk or operate a button properly and trying desperately to leave the lobby, then you have it. The controls are awfull. But the idea sound great...again... If you can't leave the lobby.

review_title: The navigation not necessarily a problem
one_reviews_text: This app will work well if you use 360 degree room scale and teleportation. Don't turn "virtually", turn in the real world. To enter an exibit, walk up to a banner and press the A button. Apart from the problems with navigation, this app is almost without flaw. Virtual art exibits, plain and simple.

I'd actually rate it 3 stars, but I put 5 to help the average. I'm sure most of the bad rating comes form peple who could not actually see the contents.

Very ambitious work, but lacks polishness on the application control. It takes for a while to figure out what to do even after the tutorial. Also, I did not like that many of the exhibitions were painting exhibitions, and not 3D works that takes advantage of VR. I see great deal of potentials in this type of applications in VR.

review_title: How to get in gallery with controller
one_reviews_text:
"RT - TELEPORT IN SOME PLACE 1 TIME
  ,PRESS ON RIGHT STICK 2 TIMES,
  MENU APPPEARS "PRESS  X FOR TABLET" - PRESS X  - IN MENU- PRESS ON  GEAR SIGN - HIGHLIGHT   "TELEPORT" AND  "SIMIULATED WALK" WITH A BUTTON- EXIT WITH B  - GO TO "ENTER" SIGN - ENTER WITH A"
i figured out it myself. wtf no instructions at all, horrible , but game is good.

This app really blew me away. I nearly didn't bother downloading because of the all the terrible reviews but I honestly don't know what these people were playing, because it clearly wasn't this! I didn't have any problems with the controls. It supports Oculus Touch and you choose between teleportation or free walking movement. You can even select your walk and turn speed preferences although I prefer to just teleport. The program has 7 different museums with dozens of paintings and artifacts in each, all life sized and well rendered. There is both text and audio narration for all the exhibits that I tested (I've only done the British musuem so far) and both the audio and written materials were excellent. This is the kind of VR experience I was dreaming of and I'd have paid good money for this. I got to see the Rosetta Stone, lots of other Egyptian artificats, the Elgin Marbles and some wonderful Assyrian and Sumerian treasures. Tomorrow I'm going to see what Roman exhibits the musuem has. If you have any interest in history, art and culture this should really be checked out. I can only assume all the one star reviews about terrible movement were based on an old build becuase it works perfectly for me and is everything I hoped a virtual musuem experience could be! More please!!!

Would really like to explore the content here but the XBox and Touch controllers are almost impossible to navigate. I seem to find it impossible to enter any of the galleries. Can you please overhaul the navigation system.
The uasabilty is just not worth it deleted as fast as possible

review_title: Sounds Amazing, I never got in the door
one_reviews_text: Sounds cool but I couldn't get out of the lobby
It just doesn't work, it did control to move a few steps in the introduction hallway,  the "enter " command just didn't work.

review_title: can someone please explain how to get in
one_reviews_text: if there is a simple guide on controls that'd help - anyone doing a 5* review please advise as rest of us are sooo frustrated!

The controls probably to be adjusted, like a pointing indicator and a little more context sensitivity in that regard, but once you've worked it out and sped up the walk/turn speed it's pretty nifty to get about. I just wanted to see more exhibits!

review_title: A taste of the greatest museums
one_reviews_text: Yes, it is a taste, and only a very limited edition from the V&A and the British Museum (one room only), the controls aren't refined but I am willing to pay like 80€ or more for one of this museums enitrely on VR.
LIke others have mentioned, the controls suck.  Wandered the lobby several times trying to enter a room, couldn't figure it out.  DELETE.
Controllers don't work, can't get out of the lobby. Not good.
There might be a good app here but the controls are unintutive and frustrating. IMPROVE THE CONTROLS! Your app will be great then.
The puzzles are 1) working out how to get out of the lobby 2) why Kevin Spacey invested in this. Both have me stumped.

The controls in this app are either incredibly unintuitive or nonfunctional. Usually, the "A" button is the default button, but in this app it does nothing. Tried it with both Xbox and Touch controllers. Like another reviewer said, the handiest button is "Quit."
The great app for who realy like history and other museum stuff... and its free! Bad control is nothing.

Don't listen to the other reviews - this app is hands down the best museum app on the Oculus store right now. With plenty of content - 5 rooms of paintings and 1 spectacular interactive exhibit - this app is really one to show off and keep coming back to. The narrations are done by professionals and are a pleasure to listen to. The only thing holding it back, as others have mentioned, is the control scheme. It's definitely confusing at first, but you can learn it. With the Touch update, movement is no longer an issue. You just point and shoot to teleport where you want to go, and use the left thumbstick for fine movements. Please don't let the other reviews hold you back from experiencing this app as it has much to offer at the low price of free!
Crashes every time I try to load.
Whoever allowed this to go live needs to be fired. Worst interface bar none. Amateur hour. Fix it or get out of the business. This crap is what isa holding VR back from the mass market
3.31 gigs. Got to be more to it . Can't get in. hold up the slait board can't take the tut..
Having the only funcitonal button be the one that retuns me to Oculus Home is useful.

Whomever made this should be banned from writing VR apps. You can't use the joystick to turn in teleport mode? Except 180 degrees. I switched to walking mode, which is literally walking speed. Trying to enter a room, I had to figure out that the icon should NOT be highlighted for it to work. But not the banner. It would be crazy to look at the banner and have that work! And then go ahead and bring up the "tablet" while in a room. It SHOWS you what the different menus are, but you can't use them. I'm not kidding, click on settings and it says "Changes app settings" or the like, but it only shows you the description of what it does- you can't actually enter the menu. After a very frustrating 10 minutes I uninstalled, never to be installed again. What a piece of sh*t.

Agree with superdave. Extremely irritating to use. Confusing as hell just to enter any room.
The UI is terrible, that's when you've deciphered it !!
currently no contols .... leading to nothing
The most educational app of the Store, a great way to learning art and history.

If you like learning this will appeal. I'm glad to see projects such as this pushing the value of VR in education. The British Museum section was where I spent most of my time and I thought it was nicely done.
Sure would love to see the content if the controls worked and I could figure out to get into the museums from the lobby.

review_title: As boring as a real museum
one_reviews_text: The resolution of the paintings is pleasantly high, and there is a narrative for each painting. But I don't look at picture of fruit in real life, and I won't do it in VR.

I opened the app. Walked around the lobby. But there was no indication as to what I was supposed to do there. No button-pressing did much of anything anywhere. So after 15 minutes of aimlessly wandering around the lobby I uninstalled the app.
Feels comfortable and looks graphically good. If you enjoy a visit to your local museum this is a good concept to experience art. If you hate visiting museums... don't review it.

If you like learning this will appeal. I'm glad to see projects such as this pushing the value of VR in education. The British Museum section was where I spent most of my time and I thought it was nicely done.
Sure would love to see the content if the controls worked and I could figure out to get into the museums from the lobby.
